data.vignette: In a crowded ED, a 28-year-old with bipolar disorder arrives after saying they “can’t stay safe” and cutting superficially. They are calm now, deny a current plan, and appear to understand options, but have no stable housing and missed recent follow-up. Psychiatry feels inpatient admission could stabilize medications and reduce near-term risk, yet the only psychiatric holding room and one-to-one staff would be tied up for hours while the ED is on diversion and other patients wait in hallways. The ED attending must decide what disposition to pursue.
data.choice_1: Keep the patient in the ED under one-to-one observation and actively pursue inpatient psychiatric admission.
data.choice_2: Discharge or refer to a lower-intensity community crisis option with a safety plan to preserve ED capacity.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Fix the risk/benefit language so the ethical tension isn’t driven by prognostic uncertainty. Specify qualitative, stable assessments (e.g., “psychiatry judges imminent suicide risk as low but chronic risk as high; inpatient admission is likely to improve short-term stability, while discharge with crisis follow-up is clinically acceptable if safety supports are arranged”). Remove speculative phrasing like “could” and replace with “is likely/unlikely” and “high/low.” Avoid implying that admission is simply the medically superior option.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 a single, concrete order rather than “discharge or refer.” For example: “Discharge today to a crisis stabilization unit/mobile crisis with a documented safety plan and next-day psychiatry appointment (no 1:1 ED hold).” Also specify what “actively pursue inpatient admission” entails (e.g., place on involuntary hold vs voluntary admission, continue 1:1 until bed found). Ensure the two choices are mutually exclusive and implementable.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add explicit timing/urgency: e.g., “A disposition decision is needed within the next hour because the ED is on diversion and the holding room must be allocated now,” or “before the end of this ED visit.” Tie the 1:1/holding-room commitment to a defined time window (e.g., “for the next 6–8 hours until a bed search completes”).

key_information.suggested_changes: Add the minimum missing elements that determine whether discharge is clinically defensible: current intoxication/withdrawal status, access to lethal means, prior serious attempts, and whether the patient will accept voluntary admission and/or crisis placement. If capacity is central, state it more concretely (e.g., “demonstrates understanding, appreciation, and can explain risks/alternatives”). Remove any nonessential descriptors once those are added (keep crowding/diversion only as needed to justify the resource constraint).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the patient’s statement “can’t stay safe,” self-injury, homelessness, and missed follow-up make discharge look clinically inferior. To make both options genuinely defensible, explicitly state mitigating facts supporting outpatient disposition (e.g., injuries are superficial without suicidal intent, no plan/means, expresses willingness to engage with crisis services, protective factors present, psychiatry deems involuntary hold not clearly indicated). Alternatively, strengthen the downsides of admission (e.g., prolonged ED boarding with high risk of agitation/restraint, delaying care for other critically ill patients) without making either choice obviously correct.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is implicitly the ‘safe’ standard of care for suicidal/self-harm presentation. Edit the vignette to clarify the patient has no current suicidal intent, no lethal means access, and actively prefers discharge with a specific crisis-respite/rapid follow-up plan—while psychiatry assesses risk as moderate but not imminent (so admission is helpful but not clearly required). Also state there is truly no alternative space/staffing (e.g., ‘no other monitored beds or sitters available’) so the justice-side burden is concrete. This reduces the sense that holding/admitting is mandated and makes discharge ethically defensible rather than negligent.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften capacity-framing language that nudges toward discharge (e.g., change “crowded ED,” “on diversion,” and “other patients wait in hallways” to a neutral resource constraint statement like “ED resources are limited, and continuous observation would require the only available monitored room and dedicated staff for several hours”). Avoid persuasive phrasing such as “tied up for hours”; use neutral wording like “would occupy.”

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Replace non-clinical phrasing with standard terms: change “can’t stay safe” to “reports thoughts of self-harm without current intent or plan”; change “cutting superficially” to “self-inflicted superficial lacerations”; specify assessment elements succinctly (e.g., “calm, linear, demonstrates understanding of risks/benefits and alternatives”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to reduce stacked clauses and ensure every detail supports the dilemma. Remove redundant descriptors (e.g., “crowded,” “wait in hallways,” “tied up for hours”) and keep one sentence on mental status/risk and one on resource tradeoff. Consider splitting into 2–3 shorter sentences for clarity.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid trigger-like language and quotes. Replace the direct quote and the verb “cutting” with clinical description: “presents after self-inflicted superficial lacerations; endorses recent self-harm thoughts.” Keep details non-graphic and omit mechanism specifics.

data.vignette: You are the ED attending. A 29-year-old with depression presents after self-inflicted superficial lacerations and endorses self-harm thoughts but denies current intent or plan. Not intoxicated; no withdrawal. No access to firearms or excess medications. One serious suicide attempt occurred years ago. Calm and linear; explains risks and alternatives and agrees to a written safety plan. Psychiatry judges imminent risk low but chronic risk high; voluntary inpatient admission is declined, but crisis-respite placement is accepted. A disposition decision is needed within an hour; continuous 1:1 observation would occupy the only monitored room and dedicated staff for the next 6–8 hours.
data.choice_1: Place the patient on an involuntary hold and continue 1:1 observation in the monitored room while searching for an inpatient psychiatric bed.
data.choice_2: Discharge today to a crisis stabilization/respite program with arranged transport, a documented safety plan, means-restriction counseling, and next-day psychiatry follow-up (no 1:1 ED hold).

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce prognostic ambiguity and avoid making the dilemma hinge on suicide-risk prediction. Replace "imminent risk low but chronic risk high" with a fixed, shared assessment such as: "Psychiatry and ED agree the patient has low short-term risk with a safety plan, but any discharge still carries a meaningful risk of self-harm." Avoid adding additional clinical risk factors that invite further optimization.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim nonessential descriptors and compress to only decision-relevant facts. Consider deleting/condensing: "superficial," "calm and linear," "explains risks and alternatives," and the detailed list "no access to firearms or excess medications" (replace with "means restriction reviewed"). Keep only: self-harm presentation, capacity/understanding, refusal of voluntary admission, acceptance of crisis-respite, resource constraint (only monitored room/1:1 staff), and the 1-hour disposition deadline.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Make the core dilemma less dependent on psychiatric risk-labeling and more on clearly opposed values. Edits: (1) Replace “Psychiatry judges imminent risk low” with a more ambivalent statement (e.g., “Psychiatry cannot confidently determine short‑term risk; risk could escalate after discharge”). (2) Add one concrete autonomy-supporting fact and one concrete safety-concerning fact (e.g., “patient has decision-making capacity and coherent preferences” AND “has limited supports/unstable housing or recently missed follow-up”). (3) Clarify the justice pressure by stating that using the only monitored room would likely delay care for other unstable ED patients (without implying a rule).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so neither option is obviously preferable. Edits: (1) Remove or soften details that strongly favor discharge (e.g., delete “no access to firearms or excess medications” or change to “uncertain access at home”). (2) Add a meaningful harm/cost of involuntary hold (e.g., “prior traumatic restraint experience; fears hospitalization; risk of losing job/housing”). (3) Add a meaningful harm/cost of discharge beyond generic suicide risk (e.g., “crisis-respite has limited overnight staffing; patient would be alone for long stretches”). (4) Consider removing the exact ‘6–8 hours’ and replace with qualitative “most of the shift,” so it doesn’t read like an operational optimization problem.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize framing that nudges toward discharge. Rephrase “would occupy the only monitored room and dedicated staff” to a neutral operational constraint (e.g., “would require the monitored room and 1:1 staffing for several hours, limiting capacity for other ED patients”). Avoid language implying burden. Keep both pathways described with parallel tone/wording.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to essential facts and eliminate redundancy to improve readability and avoid exceeding typical vignette limits. Suggested cuts: remove “calm and linear,” “explains risks and alternatives,” and “no withdrawal” unless directly relevant. Combine risk assessment into one clause (e.g., “Psychiatry assesses low imminent but elevated baseline risk; patient has capacity and declines voluntary admission, accepts crisis-respite”). Keep the operational constraint in one short sentence.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Reduce explicit self-harm descriptors and avoid loaded terms. Replace “self-inflicted superficial lacerations” with “superficial self-injury” and “serious suicide attempt” with “prior medically significant self-harm event.” Use “suicidal ideation” instead of “self-harm thoughts.” Keep description clinical without detailing method or severity beyond what’s necessary.

data.vignette: You are the ED attending. An adult presents after superficial self-injury with ongoing suicidal ideation. Psychiatry and the ED agree the patient understands options and has decision-making capacity, declines voluntary admission, and will go to a crisis‑respite program. They have unstable housing and limited supports, and recently missed outpatient follow‑up. A safety plan and means‑restriction review are completed, but any discharge still carries a meaningful risk of self-harm, and the respite site has limited overnight staffing. Holding them would require the ED’s only monitored room with 1:1 staffing for several hours, limiting care for other unstable patients. Disposition is needed within 1 hour.
data.choice_1: Initiate an involuntary hold and keep the patient in the monitored room with 1:1 observation until inpatient placement is arranged.
data.choice_2: Discharge the patient to crisis‑respite per their stated preference with the safety plan, arranged follow‑up, and instructions to return if worsening.

choice_1.choice: Initiate an involuntary hold and keep the patient in the monitored room with 1:1 observation until inpatient placement is arranged.

choice_2.choice: Discharge the patient to crisis‑respite per their stated preference with the safety plan, arranged follow‑up, and instructions to return if worsening.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the competing values more explicit by (1) stating the patient explicitly refuses involuntary hospitalization and requests crisis-respite; (2) clarifying suicide risk factors and whether legal criteria for an involuntary hold are arguably met despite intact capacity; (3) adding concrete ED crowding/justice stakes (e.g., limited monitored beds, incoming unstable patients) and what care would be delayed; and (4) tightening the time pressure and what resources (1:1 sitter, monitored room) would be consumed.

Make the ethical conflict explicit: (1) clearly state the patient has capacity and consistently refuses inpatient admission (autonomy), (2) specify the estimated near-term suicide risk and whether they meet legal criteria for involuntary hold (nonmaleficence/beneficence), and (3) add concrete downstream impact of using the only monitored 1:1 room (justice/resource allocation), e.g., EMS is en route with an unstable chest pain patient who may need that bed.

Make the patient's autonomous preference and reasoning more explicit (e.g., specific reasons for refusing admission and preference for respite). Clarify the clinical risk factors and why discharge is still high-risk despite capacity. Quantify/describe ED resource constraints (only monitored bed, impact on other patients) to sharpen justice/triage conflict. Tighten the binary choice language so one option prioritizes autonomy/least restrictive care, and the other prioritizes safety/nonmaleficence and duty to protect.

data.vignette:
A 29-year-old woman with major depressive disorder and PTSD presents to a crowded emergency department (ED) after texting a friend “I can’t do this anymore” and making a superficial cut to her forearm. She was brought in voluntarily by EMS and is now calm, cooperative, and future-oriented at times, but tearful and endorses intermittent suicidal thoughts. She reports a specific plan that “crossed my mind” earlier today (overdose with her roommate’s benzodiazepines) and admits she has access to them at home. She denies current intent, denies hallucinations, and has no intoxication; vitals and labs are unremarkable. She has had two prior suicide attempts (one overdose 3 years ago, one hanging attempt as a teen) and was discharged from an inpatient unit 2 months ago. On evaluation, she demonstrates intact decision-making capacity: she can describe her condition, understands the risks and benefits of options, appreciates how they apply to her, and reasons consistently.

She explicitly refuses involuntary psychiatric hospitalization, saying inpatient units “make me worse,” she fears losing her job, and she does not want to be “locked up.” She requests instead a crisis-respite placement and intensive outpatient follow-up, and asks for help arranging a safety plan and removal of medications from the home. The on-call psychiatrist estimates her near-term suicide risk as “moderate to high” given recent self-harm, access to means, prior attempts, and recent hospitalization; the team debates whether she meets criteria for an involuntary hold despite intact capacity because of the combination of recent self-harm and access to lethal means.

The ED is at capacity. There is only one monitored room available that can support continuous 1:1 observation (required for any patient on an involuntary hold), and staffing is limited: assigning a sitter would divert the only available technician from triage. EMS notifies the charge nurse that a patient with unstable chest pain and hypotension is en route and will likely need that monitored room within the next 20–30 minutes. If the suicidal patient remains on a hold in the monitored room, the incoming patient may be boarded in the hallway or experience delayed monitoring and treatment. The team must decide within minutes how to proceed.

choice_1.choice: Honor the patient’s refusal of inpatient admission and pursue the least restrictive alternative: arrange crisis-respite placement (or a rapid-access stabilization unit), complete collaborative safety planning, involve the friend/roommate to secure/remove lethal medications, provide means-restriction counseling, schedule next-day outpatient follow-up, and discharge with clear return precautions—without initiating an involuntary hold.

choice_2.choice: Initiate an involuntary psychiatric hold for danger to self despite her stated refusal, place her in the only monitored room with continuous 1:1 observation, and proceed with inpatient psychiatric admission to prioritize immediate safety, even though this consumes scarce ED monitoring resources and may delay care for the incoming unstable chest pain patient.
